moves.1. e4: Disappointed in my performance in the first round on Friday evening, I  decieded to re-enter. The friend I was staying with in Dayton was playing in  the 2-day schedule anyway so it wasn't that hard of a decision. This first  round on Saturday morning was only G/90, while all the others were 30/90,  SD/1 d/5.
moves.1... c5 2. Ne2: The Keres variation. My opponent was a young kid who I had a lot of rating points on. I wanted to see what he would play against this, see if I could rattle his cage at all. I always knew I would transpose into the mainline sicilian with d4 and Nd4, sometimes this can be a good  system to play if you want to delay and see what sicilian system your  opponent may be aiming for, you can always play g3, Bg2 and play a closed  sicilian if you don't like their variation.
moves.2... g6: I never really intended to  play a closed position, I just wanted to see what my opponent would do, so  now we transpose back into the mainline open sicilian.
moves.8... Na5:
Very  much out of book, black's two main options are ...d6 or ...a5
Alternative variation: 8. ... d6 9.  Qd2 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Kb1 [The variation I was looking for] 
Alternative variation: 8. ... a5  [A line I've never actually seen before, but was shown to me after the game  by another player and actually has roughly as many games in my database as  ...d6] 9. f3 d5 [And now the move is 10. Bd5 but I'm not sure I would have  found it over the board.]
moves.9. f3:
In keeping with White's play in the  mainlines, but not the way to punish Black for his move.
Alternative variation: 9. e5 Nxb3 10.  exf6 Nxa1 11. fxg7 Nxc2+ 12. Nxc2 Kxg7 13. Bxa7 f6 14. Be3 [With good  development and coordination White should have an edge here.]
moves.9... Nxb3 10. cxb3:
Probably exposes the king too much, especially since I was planning to  castle long.
Alternative variation: 10. Nxb3 [Better, and White can castle short.]
moves.10... d6 11. Qd2 Be6 12. Bh6 d5 13. Bxg7: Perhaps dangerous to  castle long here, but I wanted to roll the kingside pawns and press for the  attack!
moves.15... Rc8 16. g4: Black cannot capture on e5 of course.
moves.16... a6:
Too slow from  Black
Alternative variation: 16. ... Nxe5 17. Nxe6+ fxe6 18. Qd4 [And the knight will fall] 
Alternative variation: 16.  ... Qc7 17. Nxe6+ fxe6 18. f4 b5 19. Kb1 b4 20. Na4 [And the deficit of  castling long can be seen as the White king is very exposed. Black is not  winning outright, but has much more straightforward plans for the attack.]
moves.17. Kb1 Nb6: 17...b5 is very natural here before placing the knight on b6.
moves.18. h4 Rh8: An odd move, hoping to contest the h-file but I need not open it  if I do not want to, and this takes the rook away from the attacking forces.
moves.19. h5 Qd7 20. h6+:
Now bringing the rook back into the game will be very  difficult.
Alternative variation: 20. Nxe6+ fxe6 21. hxg6 hxg6 22. Qg5 Qc7 23. Ne2 [Black cannot  try to capture the knight.] Kf7 (23. ... Qc2+ 24. Ka1 Qxe2 [And now mate  comes.] 25. Qxe7+ Kg8 26. Qxe6+ Kg7 27. Qf6+ Kg8 28. Rxh8# ) 24. Nd4 Qd7 25.  f4 [Perhaps a stronger line for White.]
moves.20... Kg8 21. Qg5: Bringing all the  pressure to bear on Black's king.
moves.22. Rhg1: Alternative variation: 22. Rdg1  [Perhaps better to keep one of the rooks on the h-file.]
moves.22... b5 23. f4 Qe8:
Black is in trouble now.
Alternative variation: 23. ... b4 [The move I had thought Black would  try, but White still has plenty.] 24. f5 bxc3 25. fxe6 c2+ 26. Nxc2 fxe6 (26.  ... Qxe6 [Still not great as the knight can get tempo by returning to d4] 27.  Nd4 Qb6 [So that e6 does not come with Queen threatening tempo and to attack  the knight.] 28. Nf5 Re8 29. Nxe7+ Kf8 30. Nxd5 Qc6 ) 27. Nd4 Nc7 28. Rgf1
moves.24. f5 Bd7 25. Nxd5 Kf8 26. fxg6 hxg6 27:
Looking for mate down the  h-file, but there's a stronger try!
Alternative variation: 27. e6 [A move I had looked at over the  board, but decided to go for the line I could see fully.] Nc7 (27. ... f6  [The move that I thought saved Black] 28. Nxf6 Nb6 (28. ... exf6 29. Qxf6+  Kg8 30. Qg7# ) 29. Rgf1 [and Black's busted.] ) 28. exf7 Qxf7 29. Rgf1
moves.27... Kg7: Alternative variation: 27. ... Rxh7 [Leads to the same]
moves.28. Rgh1 Rxh7 29. Rxh7+ Kxh7 30. Rh1+ Kg:
Plenty strong, in fact I thought my opponent would resign here,  but misses the mate.
Alternative variation: 31. Qh6 f6 32. Qh8+ Kf7 33. Rh7#
moves.31... Qxe7 32. Qxe7 Nb6 33. Qf6 Rc1+: And my opponent throws in the spite check.
